30.title: Why do people just walk past?! It's amazing!
30.review: This gallery always seems quiet, as you come to the gallery and see the crowds at Trafalgar Square and the many tourists scuttling past it always shocks me how so many simply ignore this galleries existence.Having always enjoyed history at school this gallery is amazing! Added to that there are more modern paintings and photographs of celebrities. So I'd say there is something for everyone.And best of all its free and right next door to another fab gallery and close to lots of cafes so you can always bob out for lunch!

31.title: Short trip through British history
31.review: I actually liked this better than the adjacent National Gallery. It's essentially an art museum for history buffs. You get to see thousands of portraits of all those famous Brits, from kings to poets to physicists throughout Britain's glorious and fascinating history. In a nutshell, it's a who's who of Britain, wrapped up in one museum.There was also a bizarre but memorable temporary exhibition of various athletes (possibly gearing up for London 2012) during my visit. Inside, you'll find a bunch of athletes and olympians posing nude for AIDS awareness, including French footballer Thierry Henry, one of the Williams tennis sisters, and of course...wait for it.....Buffalo Bills wideout TERRELL "T.O." OWENS! There was also a downright creepy "portrait," which was a continuous loop of a video of David Beckham asleep.Very much different from the National Gallery. I'd say the National Portrait Gallery is well worth a visit in its own right.

32.title: Wonderful way to spend a few hours
32.review: This free gallery is well set-out and is a wonderful way to spend a relaxed few hours in the busy capital. You can travel through the ages, viewing royalty, politicians or Damon from Blur. Simply my favourite gallery of a wide and excellent choice in London, not to be missed.

33.title: Could have spent all day here
33.review: The museum is full of several floors of all kinds of paintings and art and is most interesting, as well as a respite when you're tired of walking in the hot outdoors. The cafe at the top of the museum I cannot comment on, because we sat there for 30 minutes before finally leaving while nobody came to take our order.

34.title: The facility is closed visited 26 Sept 2020
34.review: Closed for refurbishment until 2023.I was informed of this by a staff member at the Mall Gallery. It will be missed

35.title: David Hockney - Drawing From Life
35.review: A fascinating look at Hockney's early work and finding out why he worked the way he did. The exhibition is well presented and worth seeing while you can.

36.title: Wonderful lunch
36.review: Set overlooking Trafalgar Square this is a great place to enjoy a first class experience for lunch - a little pricey- but well worth it.  The cheese plate gives an excellent selection of British cheeses with great chutney!

37.title: Lovely place to spend some time
37.review: The portraits are many and varied, too many to take in all at once. We only had an hour and focussed on the Tudor and Stuart ones which are simply beautiful.

38.title: Hockney we salute you!
38.review: Prebooked our tickets to see the latest David Hockney portraits exhibition and we were so excited to be there. The exhibition is quite small but the portraits are wonderful especially the ones of the artists mother. It was very hot inside the rooms and this made it uncomfortable to stay very long. We were through in 45minutes but perhaps this is the idea! David Hockney is a genius. The short film of him flipping through his sketch book from LA to Normandy was a highlight for me.

39.title: Excellent Museum, worth the visit
39.review: After visiting most art museums in London; I left the National Portrait Gallery to the last. I was hesitant to visit a museum of "selfies"; I thought it would be boring. I admit that I was completely wrong. I enjoyed a lot this museum, specially the old paintings. This is a place for history buffs. If you have seen the movie "the favourite" there is a portrait of the Duchess of Marlborough near to Queen Anne; which I think it was very appropriate. You will see all the paintings of famous British scientist, politicians and royalty that have become part of history books.  The Cafe was excellent; I strongly recommend you to have your meal or snack in this place. On the downside, the XX century paintings were not that good, I found them pretentious with some exceptions.  My recommendation is not to overlook this wonderful museum in your next visit to London.

20.title: Great gallery with fantastic roof top views from the restaurant.
20.review: This national treasure has many portraits assembled over the years. But, for me, the highlight is the Portrait Restaurant, at the top of the gallery, open lunchtimes and also in the evening if the gallery is open. Fantastic seasonal menus with great views over the rooftops of Westminster, Whitehall, Theatreland and Covent Garden. A bit like the view from the roof of Il Duomo, Milan!

21.title: Still great
21.review: This is a great way to spend a dull grey saturday morning. Started off with a fantastic coffee and lemon drisel cake in there cafe, great service , they have really improved things here 100%. Now the art fantastic collection, i find its better to just wander around  .and let it all soake in a great visit

22.title: Portrait Gallery - Free Museum
22.review: Free entry (voluntary donations)Impressive portraits even if you are not an art buff - well worth a visit.

23.title: An amazing must see. One of my favorites in London
23.review: If you Love art, this is the place for you. Even if art is not for you, you will be amazed. An Incredible collection !

24.title: Loved it
24.review: Its not super busyYou won't get trodden on or walked over by tourists Its not going to cost you 2 weeks worth of wages to visitSome beautiful pictures and artwork.Lots to learn, see and doLovely restaurant food well priced and tastyBreath taking artwork (in my opinion) Vibrant easy to navigate around10/10 - A must for anyone interested in art!

25.title: Afternoon Tea
25.review: Went for afternoon tea and the place was virtually devoid of customers, the cream in the blackforest gateau looked as though it had been frozen and defrosted as the colour from the cherries was bleeding into it.  Had to go to the service area to ask for the bill despite being the only customers in there at the time as the staff were all chatting amongst themselves, not a way to run a business.                                                                                          I actually went in May 2011 but this was not an option, if you want to be served when having afternoon tea do not come here!

26.title: Queen special exhibition
26.review: I did not go to the see the permanent collection but the Queen Diamond Jubilee special exhibition, and it was amazing. You can have a much better understanding about the queen and the royal family since they allocate the pictures and portrait with a timeline since the coronation til current.

27.title: Disappointing
27.review: Had expected so much more, but the museum is much smaller than I'd hoped and not nearly as vibrant or exiting as it could be made.

28.title: Picture this
28.review: I popped in to see the exhibits mainly for the annual BP awards. It was a busy day when I went so you might inadvertently end up jostling when reading the information cards.Portrait selections are based on the significance of the sitter rather than the artist. They are not all paintings and can include photographs , drawings, sculpture as well as the more formal paintings.The NPG has portraits of historically important and famous British people. It also has recent portraits and they do not all tend to be celebrities neither. Newer portraits I saw included actor/writer/director Noel Clarke.The gallery was opened in its current location in 1896. Famous exhibits include the Chandos portrait of William Shakespeare, it may be the only actual depiction of Shakespeare. There is also the Holbein's portrait of Henry VIII.In previous visits I focussed more on the historical figures such as  monarchs and politicians. This time I looked at more contemporary figures which tied neatly with the BP competition.

29.title: Brilliant ... truly amazing.
29.review: Well worth a visit.  It is free and really reflects the very best portraits and a brilliant span of British History.  A MUST SEE!Top Tip: - If you have an iPhone get the NPG App before your visit as the guided tours on there are superb and cheaper than renting an auido guide at the gallery.

10.title: A Visual Feast of British History
10.review: This Gallery has many excellent (and famous) portraits.  The displays are mainly organized by historical periods with sub-categories by subject.  For example, I particularly enjoyed seeing famous scientists and engineers from various times.  There was also a spectacular display of modern portraits on the ground floor.The displays include informative side bars that tell the historical stories in sufficient detail to give you a real sense of the roles of the individuals in the particular period.  Of course, it helps to have some knowledge of the history of the British Empire as a scaffold onto which to view this immense collection.It is possible to see a great deal of this collection in 3-4 hours, although one could linger longer if time allows.  This is a "don't miss" destination either for lovers of art or for students of history.  And open to the public without charge.  An astounding collection!

11.title: A very entertaining museum - with a restaurant on top!
11.review: The National Portrait Gallery in the heart of London is a very well made museum. What I like about it is the chronological set-up of the floors, so you can start in the top floor and walk your way through the centuries - realizing how much the way of creating portraits has changed throughout history. A "secret" tip is the restaurant on the top floor: Reservation in advance is necessary, but then you can enjoy a marvellous view over the roof landscape of London!http://www.npg.org.uk/

12.title: The vitual tour is terrible
12.review: I did the virtual tour and it was terrible. I couldn't move, which meant all the portraits were far away (and barely visible). The 'galleries' were just little snip its of the real thing, so I couldn't see all the stuff (even if I could move, which I couldn't, i would still miss loads of portraits).  On top of all of that, it was really hard to rotate the view because the rotation was really quick (this made me feel VERY dizzy)! It is terrible, a tech flop. So don't do the virtual tour. Mark my words!

13.title: Another wonderful museum
13.review: The National Portrait Gallery contains a large assortment of portraits - with a focus on British subjects and history (at least that's what I saw, anyway). In exploring the galleries, I got a brief lesson in the people behind periods of British history, which I enjoyed. I also found this museum less crowded than the neighboring National Gallery, so I felt I was able to enjoy and take in the works more.

14.title: Is this a Scam
14.review: The gallery offered on its webb site 5 tickets for pensioners to see the Pre Raphaelite Sisters Exhibition on certain days between 10-11amOn Nov 18th we arrived at the gallery before 11am and were told there were no tickets left.Having travelled all the way to London we were then faced with paying the full ticket amount of 17 each. Checking later on the Gallery webb site the is no mention that there are a limited no of tickets each day at this price. I have written to them but have not had a replyIS THIS A SCAM TO ATTRACT MANY PEOPLE TO THE GALLERY UNDER FALSE PRETENSES IN ORDER TO EXTRACT A FULL PRICE TICKET PAYMENT FROM PENSIONERS WHO THOUGHT THEY WOULD ONLY BE PAYING 5

15.title: Fascinating Pre-Raphaelite Sisters exhibition
15.review: The NPG is always a treasure trove of interesting art and its special exhibitions are no exception. This exploration of the role of certain women in the Pre-Raphaelite  art movement is very well worth seeing. Its a comprehensive view of their influence, whether as wives or muses of the male artists or as artists in their own right. The numerous information captions are detailed and very helpful. The artworks on display are of course sublime.

16.title: Free culture
16.review: A great surprise, I went inside the gallery just by chance, and was surprised with the amazing art works in there and also the organization of the museum.A place I look forward to come back ween I visit London an other time!

17.title: Can't beat free admission
17.review: Enjoyed my visit to the National Portrait Gallery. Admission is free and the collection is more than worth the price.

18.title: Utterly wonderful
18.review: We in Britain should be so proud of the richness of our history and the ability to see historic paintings for free. The quality and range of the portraits is astounding. No tourist visiting London should miss this. In particlular the Tudor and Stuart rooms with their 500 year old paintings is a wonder. I cannot speak highly enough of this venue.

19.title: Better than expected... With Dame Dench
19.review: On my way to James park (for some recovery and coffee in the sun) I stumpled across this museum of portraits. Several floors of paintings, busts and photos. Did the museum without audioguide but managed by reading the text next to each item. Being sort of a nerd interested in British history made it easier to get the picture so to say. If you havent so much knowledge Do take an audioguide otherwise this can get to be a pretty stuffy visit.Well worth visiting. Lots of well known paintings that is nice to IRL.Admission free as of may 2019.

0.title: Smiling Faces In The Galleries
0.review: The National Portrait has always been one of our favourite London galleries and we often visit the temporary exhibitions. Therefore, being in town for a theatre performance, we were pleased to add the Martin Parr presentation. The name may not be familiar, but almost everybody will know his work from the pre programme inserts on BBC One. There were many happy faces enjoying the images and it made for an excellent start to a very good day.

1.title: Definitely worth a visit.
1.review: This is one of my favourite art galleries in London and I loved the Tudor collection.The portrait of Jane Austin was another one I particularly liked.  Apparently, it is the only portrait of the famous novelist in existence and was sketched by her sister, Cassandra.I also liked the personal collections of Audrey Hepburn.  There were 35 photographs of the actress, including photos taken when she was nine years old.  Some of the photos are well known vintage magazine covers and famous fashion shoots; others have never been seen in the UK.We were able to move around with ease as this gallery is not normally as crowded as some of the other art galleries in London.The National Portrait Gallery is definitely worth a visit and its free!

2.title: An excellent gallery.
2.review: The National Portrait Gallery is an art gallery in London housing a collection of portraits of historically important and famous people.  It was the first portrait gallery in the world when it was opened in 1856.  The gallery moved in 1896 to its current site at St. Martins Place, off Trafalgar Square, and adjoining the National Gallery.The main purpose of our visit was to see the Tudor collection, because I have always been fascinated by the history of Henry VIII and his six wives.  Also, I wanted to see the portraits of Sir Winston Churchill. We were able to get up really close to the portraits to see what they actually looked like and the detail was excellent; there was also information about each portrait for you to read.  I particularly liked the portraits of Queen Elizabeth I.Definitely worth a visit.

3.title: Lovely Stop for an Afternoon of History
3.review: Just spent several hours enjoying the National Portrain Gallery.  This is a great place to gain a comprehensive look of the Kings and Queens of England, along with other notable historical figures. I suggest starting on the top, then moving down, which follows the flow of the years in which they were painted. Two important hints that the guidebooks won't tell you. Don't get the audio tour- while it is very informative and has some nice voice clips and background information, it isn't necessary. There is sufficient information next to each portrait to have an idea of the person's significance.  Secondly, don't miss the only portrait of Jane Austen, which is quite easy to skip. It is tiny, and in a poorly lit case (to protect it from the light). I saw many people walk right by it without noticing, only looking at the larger portraits on the walls. To find the current locations of this portrait, and some of the other famous ones, either look it up beforehand on the web, or look it up on the computers at the museum- the map will not tell you!

4.title: The Wow Factor!
4.review: In view of reading and watching Wolf Hall and various Tudor related programmes on TV recently, I took myself once again to the Tudor Rooms at the National Portrait Gallery.   It was yet again a joy to see these brilliant works of art looking as though they were painted yesterday. The atmosphere in the gallery is just right for these brilliant paintings. The lighting is low and the information about each painting is well produced and adequate.  The details in the costumes is amazing and although I have visited many times before I felt it was a new experience. I would persuade anyone who has not been to the Gallery before to go and spend an hour with the Tudors and hopefully be as enchanted as I was by them.

5.title: Thank goodness for David Bailey!
5.review: I've been to this gallery several times & to be honest, old portrait of Lord or Lady Whoever isn't really my 'cup of tea' although I must admit the collection is very impressive & without doubt very expensive.David Bailey the famous photographer has a really good collection of his work on at the moment. David has a sense of humour & therefore doesn't take himself too seriously. Well worth a visit to see this exhibition.

6.title: Everytime
6.review: I love it! I always come here when I visit London. Even if it is just for 30 minutes. It spans centuries of portraits. If you are lucky you come here when the BP Portrait Awards are showing to gain an overview of modern art and styles - impressive. The faces will linger in your mind.Tip: don't forget to have high tea in the portrait gallery and don't forget to reserve in advance. The views over London combines with the dishes are superb - friendly French waiters included...

7.title: Calm amidst the bustle
7.review: It's funny how the NPG is just around the corner from the business of Trafalgar Square and yet as you walk in you feel a calming influence.It's free although confusingly there is a large area for tickets (for the other exhibitions going on). The paintings are nicely laid out with (I think) the correct positioning between them.If you are feeling seriously flush and want a superb view, afternoon tea has quite simply some of the best views of London. At 27.50 each it really isn't a bargain though.

8.title: David Bailey's Stardust exhibition
8.review: Maybe this was never going to be the show for me. I don't know which I loathe more - celebrity culture or the fashion industry.Bailey is primarily a black and white photographer - thankfully; because the colour pictures in the show are truly awful.The images of David and his chums are sometimes stomach churning. "This is me and Dali." "This is me and Andy Warhol". "Did you know I was friends with the Rolling Stones?"The show is utterly vacuous. Still, if you go upstairs in the National Portrait Gallery, you are in for a treat. The NPG is wonderful. And it's free.

9.title: You Will Like It - And Not Only The Gallery
9.review: We spent 90 minutes immersed in fantastic paintings AFTER 3 hours at the Tower Of London until our feet ached before taking a well deserved rest.  A flight attendant on our American Airlines flight gave us a tip that the third floor restaurant here enjoys great views over the rooftops of downtown London and she was right.  You sit right over Trafalgar Circle and can easily see Big Ben and Parliament from this birds-eye perch.  Lots of windows in the restaurant and a nice bar - all with great views.  And the free museum. WOW!   Terry Hunefeld and Ann Dunham - San Diego (Borrego Springs)

0.title: Splendid park
0.review: Kensington Gardens is the park next to Hyde park and if you explore one you should explore the other, lot of paths to wander and beautiful Italian gardens, fountains and statues like the two bears and Peter Pan.

1.title: Beautiful with a calming vibe.
1.review: I have basically grown up going here living very close. I love it here particularly around the pound and watching the birds. Its so beautiful going around the palace and have a connection to nature. For younger kids, the Princess Diana Playground is perfect, however almost always busy so you must keep a very close eye of your child. For anyone, I would really recommend a trip if you live in London or staying here. You can also find many facilities around the park like one of my fave the ice skating rink in the winter then a nice walk in the park!

2.title: The gardens are free and beautiful
2.review: A beautiful garden to spend a few hours , you can access them without going to the place and when the place is open you will also have access to the sunken gardens

3.title: A quieter more natural experience
3.review: On the other side of the bridge from Hyde Park, you can enjoy a more peaceful, more natural park. The criss crossing paths make it feel almost private at times but with occasional monuments, statues and stop points, theres plenty to look at.

4.title: Great drama
4.review: Love this park for ages :smiling_face_with_heart-eyes: so romantic for all in London Town in this era of the pandemic  and  brexit

5.title: Fantastic Garden with park and Swans in lake. It's so soothing
5.review: One of the largest gardens in central London. Spacious green area and plenty walking paths. Can be crowded during weekends and holidays, which, in a way,is testimony for its popularity.

6.title: Perfect for a walk
6.review: I came here with a friend to eat our sandwiches on one of the many benches. We had a delightful walk and the park is large enough to easily maintain social distancing.

7.title: Princess Diana Dresses
7.review: I Love Royalty!!!!So much to see Wimbledon on next tripWe need to be blessed and vaccines working for allComing back soon.  I promise. Louise and Keith

8.title: Lovely park!
8.review: Plenty of green space with Round Water in front of Kensington Palace. Saw a black swan in the water. Theres a Dianas memorial playground for kids. Great place for a stroll. Theres a cafe by the Palace too and plenty of open air seating.

9.title: A little stroll
9.review: December 2019 Myself and my partner were staying over the road from here at the Hilton Hyde Park so we assumed this was part of Hyde Park but we found that it is in fact Kensington Gardens. We were only staying the one night and on the morning of checkout had a little walk around. It was a bright cold day and it was lovely to take a stroll around heading to the lake and towards the palace. A nice little visit I think we only saw a small part of it but what we did see was a well kept park with some wildlife such as swans and squirrels.

30.title: Great stadium
30.review: Great place to watch a match (though tickets are a bit pricey for top tier matches). Always clean and tidy. Staff are very friendly and helpful. Food is reasonably priced for this sort of place and queues were not too long. Lovely ground coffee. Be aware it is card only. No queuing to get in or for toilets, including the ladies (plenty of them).Only downside is getting out of the stadium and queuing for underground. It's better to avoid the queue at Arsenal station and walk up to Finsbury Park (about 10 minutes walk).Won't comment on the football atm!!!

31.title: Legends Stadium Tour with Charlie George
31.review: This was superb, as good as I could have hoped for. I've been a long time fan since the 1971 'Double' and Charlie George was the perfect host. Saw the whole stadium and ground from top to bottom. His knowledge of the club, players past and present and many anecdotes were very entertaining. Best afternoon spent for a long time!

32.title: Great hospitality, poor football
32.review: I could only get tickets for club level, which cost me 103.50 each. No queue to get in, free programme and team sheet on arrival. Nice Camden Lager on tap and had a nice burger from one of the restaurants, although 18.50 for burger, chips & coke was a bit steep. Plenty of seat space and a fantastic view of the pitch. Obviously I came to watch the football which is really where the whole experience falls down. The atmosphere was subdued, which can partly be explained but the awful performance Arsenal put it. It really was very boring and the players didnt actually seem to want to win the match!Great stadium, great hospitality but unfortunately the main product on the pitch was really poor.

33.title: Excellent-well organised tour and friendly staff
33.review: Came to the Emirates Stadium with friends whilst visiting from the states, was a great visit although restricted by time - staff were extremely polite and thanks to Ciaran for a helping hand with pictures. Great experience, would definitely recommend!!!!

34.title: Impressive from outside, average on inside
34.review: From the street, this stadium makes a striking appearance. But its a different story inside. I always wanted to see an English premier league game, so I chose arsenal for convenience sake.I found out afterwards that arsenal seats are the most expensive in the EPL. I also heard a lot of negative stuff about arsenal fans. Seats werent cheap but I bought at the last minute. The seat itself was great except for the fact that proximity to the field exposed me to the elements, namely a light rain. Had I sat further back, that would not have been a problem. Not many loos at this place so there were long lines to get in. Also, long queues for beer. Quite a difference from Wembley where queues were minimal.The queue to enter the nearby underground station after the game was horrific. I advise either leave the match early, or find a pub to have a pint or two before going to the station.

35.title: Excellent for families - come when there is no match
35.review: I took my family on the Emirates tour. My eldest son is an Arsenal fan as am I and my late father was also. I had seen Arsenal play Leyton Orient in the 70s but never made it to highbury. So this was a treat for all of us and it really delivered. We did not do match day (could not get tickets) and am pleased we didn't as we had full access to pitch side, dugouts, VIP sections, changing rooms.Guided by an audio/visual guide - we were walked through the tour in a very atmospheric manner. Great day out for family. Fantastic stadium. Museum not to be missed either.

36.title: Great Stadium - if only we had a Manager & Team to match...
36.review: As a decades-long Arsenal Fan/Member, (who loved the atmosphere at Highbury), I now greatly enjoy the opportunity to come to the magnificently-modern  "Emirates" a few times a year.Getting there by "Tube" (we use the Piccadilly Line - exiting at Holloway Road) is extremely easy, the stewarding is well-organised, the merchandise in the  "Armoury" Shop is seductively brilliant (you could easily spend a fortune here, but there are attractive items at all price-levels), and entry to the Stadium itself is smoothly handled by all involved.As before, our "Seats" were on the North Bank, home to many staunch "Gooners" - I say "Seats", because they don't sit here, preferring to stand throughout the Match, which is a bit problematic for those "vertically challenged" (particularly Kids) - I don't have a problem, as I'm over 6 Ft. tall, but "M" (my "Better Half") is not quite so lucky.Anyway, this time around, on a quite cold, and intermittently wet, November Saturday afternoon, we were playing Wolves - a Team which, in normal times, we could reasonably expect to beat, especially "At Home". But these are far from "normal times" : our Team gave yet another anemic display, with questionable tactics, and some highly doubtful substitutions by our current Manager. For their part, Wolves were organised and sturdy (at times cynical) in defence, lively and effective in the breakaway. There was certainly little to cheer on the "North Bank"!We were fortunate, in my view, to escape with a 1-1 Draw, and - not for the first time - as our Team underperforms, and we inevitably drift away from at least a "Top 4" position, are we paying a severe price for recruiting an apparently Grade 2/3 Coach/Manager?With these sobering thoughts, we made our way back from "Emirates" ; the "Arsenal" Tube Station is certainly nearer to our exit Gates, but it gets backed-up with crowds very quickly, and you're likely to end-up (often in the rain) standing for quite a time, as the Queue/Line inches forward very slowly. Over the years we've found it much better to head-off to the right of the exiting throngs, and take a slightly longer walk to "Finsbury Park" Station, where you will usually find yourself seated on a Tube Train very promptly - as we did, again, on this occasion.Enjoy "Emirates Stadium" - but don't expect a great Team performance under this Coach/Manager!

37.title: More like a visit to a theatre.
37.review: Lovely big stadium comfy seats and good views. Trouble is no atmosphere.  Home fans seems to think they are at a theatre rather than a live football match. The number of tourists in the club shop it's difficult to know who the real fans are . Drinks in the stadium are limited to just 3 drinks . Larger ,pale ale and cider.and the staff all seem to be confused as to how to serve a large crowd quickly.

38.title: Emirates Stadium
38.review: I went to see Arsenal at Emirates Stadium. Arsenal are my favourite team and I was gladIgot to see them play and win the game. Pele scored 2 goals and Arsenal won the game. The game was well organised and the Stadium is worth a visit. It can seat 20,000 people. The game was enjoyable and the Arsenal fans were supportive of the team.

39.title: Big stadium filled to capacity!
39.review: Easy to get to in Central London, the underground has a station at the stadium. They handle the crowds well getting people with security and bag checks. Pretty easy to move around inside. Food and beer selection is pretty lame just burgers and hot dogs and two types of beer and one cider to select from . On a positive side it does make choosing what have easy. All payments are by card. Seats were very good size compared to US sports venue. When leaving use Finsbury Park Underground where there was no queuing ...Arsenal station had thousands in the queue. Arsenal tired Crystal Palace on our visit!

20.title: Boring
20.review: They Only talk About histore and i dont Care it is propper boring and the games are boring the team are boring ARSENAL ARE BORING from a neutral fan

21.title: Sheffield United
21.review: Visited stadium for Premier League match, Sheffield United. Exellent facilities, friendly helpful staff, a vast improvement on our experience at Manchester City!

22.title: Lifetime Experience
22.review: I attended the Wolves-Gunners match in early November, a 1-1 draw. Despite the outcome, I enjoyed a lifetime experience seeing a Premiership game at Emirates. My seats were in the Club Level, with access to a private suite, offering a great view of the match.The Armoury store provided me with an opportunity to load up on Arsenal gear. I can't wait to return and attend another game!

23.title: Awesome service
23.review: I recently visited the Arsenal Armoury store looking for ideas for gifts for my family of boys who are mad Arsenal fans, Luckily I was greeted by a gentleman called Mark who was amazing. His knowledge of the history of the club and his pride in working for the club was very evident. His suggestions for gifts worked out so well for my family. This man could sell ice to eskimos, so be warned!! Mark was patient, hilarious and a great advertisement for the club. The next time I visit the store, I will make sure I look out for Mark. I suggest you do the same. Brilliant.

24.title: Great stadium
24.review: visited the Emirates for the Arsenal v Leeds cup tie.great views of the pitch from the side - located in the upper level in line with the edge of the penalty area. Comfy seats.Food and drink very good and reasonable prices for a stadium.

25.title: First Class
25.review: We attended an Arsenal march in Dec and came away very impressed by the Emirates and it's staff.  We had club level tickets and the food options were plentiful and we enjoyed the Camden Road Brewing options as well.  Overall game day experience was impeccable except for that late lapse against Chelsea.....

26.title: A brilliant stadium
26.review: I have visited the emirates 5 or 6 time before for tours, football matches and concerts. This really is a first class stadium. The tours can be done either with or without a guide. Throughout the tour you get a real sense of the story of the club from when it was founded all the way through to the modern day. You get to go inside the changing rooms, press conference room, directors box, directors seating area, the players tunnel and the dugout. It really is a great experience for any football fan. If you are attending a game there literally isn't a bad seat in the stadium (unless you're sat in front of a pole) drinks and food are a little on the expensive side but that is to be expected in any stadium or arena these days. I attended a coldplay concert here a few years ago and the atmosphere was amazing and to this day I still remember thousands of people walking down the street afterwards singing viva la vida.

27.title: Brilliant Stadium - Even for a non-Arsenal Fan!
27.review: Brought clients to the Arsenal stadium as part of an FA cup away game. Loved every minute, the staff were very helpful and the stadium was clean and tidy. A really great stadium to watch a game with top class facilities. The food on offer in the stadium concourse is also very good, although 14 is pretty pricey for a burger and chips but this is generally standard for away concourses.

28.title: Visit at your favorite club
28.review: If you are an Arsenal fan, this is a must. Its expensive, but I would not have missed it. 60.000 can not be mistaken - every second weekend

29.title: Club match, So Awesome
29.review: We got the train from Bedfordshire, Easy access. 60,000 people. Chants are deafening and exciting Big turn out for a cup match. No drinking inside the stadium. You can get drinks before & at half time.If you are not from the U. K well worth the experience including walking from the station to the game. Staff were great

10.title: Legends Tour of the stadium
10.review: Fabulous experience from start to finish.  Greeted by Pete and Lee and made very welcome by two charming and helpful men. Funny too.  Nigel Winterburn was a very charming, informative and friendly guide for this special occasion.  We learnt a lot (from one of our heroes) about this wonderful stadium. We can certainly recommend the whole experience - excellent value for money.

11.title: Great Ground With Quiet Home Fans...
11.review: Great stadium, probably my fifth visit or so as a Hammer and one of my favourite away grounds  to visit. The seats are unusually large and comfortable and the home support are lovely and quiet so its very easy to out-sing them.Easy to grab a beer and pie at half time and not too far from Highbury & Islington station with all its connections.Absolutely robbed though.. :hammer_and_pick:

12.title: Atmosphere was just like a library
12.review: The stadium itself isnt all that bad a bit pricey for drinks and all once inside but its clean and considering its been around for a while now, it has definitely stood the test of time. Poor atmosphere once in the ground by the Arsenal fans which has earned this place its library status which I can see why just by visiting.

13.title: We did qualified
13.review: OLYMPIAKOS! We traveled from Greece to London for this match even though we had lost the first leg 0-1. We did qualify in the overtime and the moments were unforgettable!I will never forget that match in my life. It was like a dream!

14.title: Very Good Stadium
14.review: Attended as an away supporter  for a football match. Outside stewards were very good . Food and drink area a bit more spacious then most places . Prices typical London.Seating good and good atmosphere.Access etc good .A good experience all round , apart from the result and that's not the stadium's fault.It's easily got to from tube stations and although there are restrictions after the game crowds dispersed fairly quickly.

15.title: Excellent access for disabled spectators!
15.review: Paid my first visit to the Emirates Stadium yesterday to watch Arsenal vs. Everton. Disability access is excellent and the whole atmosphere was very pleasant. The roads around the stadium can get very congested on match days, but once you get to the ground it's all positive. And to top if off, the game was very good too with Arsenal coming out as 3-2 winners!

16.title: Classy outfit
16.review: Visited here for a tour! What a truely breathtaking stadium, the club just ooses class from top to bottom, rich in history and trophy cabinet full of crockery!

17.title: Excellent Venue
17.review: I attended Opportunity 2020, the venue is stunning as is the level of service once you got past the aggressive gate keeper. Pat working on the cloak room is an absolute asset to the club. Nothing was an inconvenience to her and she had a friendly word for everyone. Pat thank you, you made my visit.

18.title: First class Football experience
18.review: Great stadium, excellent game. 4-0 come on the gunners!  staff were attentive, friendly and helpful.  Had a great experience.

19.title: Fun experience
19.review: We attended an Arsenal soccer game at Emirates stadium and had a good time. The Arsenal underground station is nearby and the stadium is easy to find. It was also easy to find the closest entrance for our seats. The line to get in was not long. It was also only a short wait to purchase refreshments during half-time. The only down-side were the people in the front standing, rather than sitting, such that everyone in all the rows behind them were forced to stand for the entire game, including us. We and several others, asked the game attendants about asking patrons to sit down, but they werent willing to do so, even though many spectators said they used to do that so that everyone could see. They should reconsider that practice.

20.title: Splendid park
20.review: Kensington Gardens is the park next to Hyde park and if you explore one you should explore the other, lot of paths to wander and beautiful Italian gardens, fountains and statues like the two bears and Peter Pan.

21.title: Beautiful with a calming vibe.
21.review: I have basically grown up going here living very close. I love it here particularly around the pound and watching the birds. Its so beautiful going around the palace and have a connection to nature. For younger kids, the Princess Diana Playground is perfect, however almost always busy so you must keep a very close eye of your child. For anyone, I would really recommend a trip if you live in London or staying here. You can also find many facilities around the park like one of my fave the ice skating rink in the winter then a nice walk in the park!

22.title: The gardens are free and beautiful
22.review: A beautiful garden to spend a few hours , you can access them without going to the place and when the place is open you will also have access to the sunken gardens

23.title: A quieter more natural experience
23.review: On the other side of the bridge from Hyde Park, you can enjoy a more peaceful, more natural park. The criss crossing paths make it feel almost private at times but with occasional monuments, statues and stop points, theres plenty to look at.

24.title: Great drama
24.review: Love this park for ages :smiling_face_with_heart-eyes: so romantic for all in London Town in this era of the pandemic  and  brexit

25.title: Fantastic Garden with park and Swans in lake. It's so soothing
25.review: One of the largest gardens in central London. Spacious green area and plenty walking paths. Can be crowded during weekends and holidays, which, in a way,is testimony for its popularity.

26.title: Perfect for a walk
26.review: I came here with a friend to eat our sandwiches on one of the many benches. We had a delightful walk and the park is large enough to easily maintain social distancing.

27.title: Princess Diana Dresses
27.review: I Love Royalty!!!!So much to see Wimbledon on next tripWe need to be blessed and vaccines working for allComing back soon.  I promise. Louise and Keith

28.title: Lovely park!
28.review: Plenty of green space with Round Water in front of Kensington Palace. Saw a black swan in the water. Theres a Dianas memorial playground for kids. Great place for a stroll. Theres a cafe by the Palace too and plenty of open air seating.

29.title: A little stroll
29.review: December 2019 Myself and my partner were staying over the road from here at the Hilton Hyde Park so we assumed this was part of Hyde Park but we found that it is in fact Kensington Gardens. We were only staying the one night and on the morning of checkout had a little walk around. It was a bright cold day and it was lovely to take a stroll around heading to the lake and towards the palace. A nice little visit I think we only saw a small part of it but what we did see was a well kept park with some wildlife such as swans and squirrels.

17.title: Princess Diana Dresses
17.review: I Love Royalty!!!!So much to see Wimbledon on next tripWe need to be blessed and vaccines working for allComing back soon.  I promise. Louise and Keith

18.title: Lovely park!
18.review: Plenty of green space with Round Water in front of Kensington Palace. Saw a black swan in the water. Theres a Dianas memorial playground for kids. Great place for a stroll. Theres a cafe by the Palace too and plenty of open air seating.

19.title: A little stroll
19.review: December 2019 Myself and my partner were staying over the road from here at the Hilton Hyde Park so we assumed this was part of Hyde Park but we found that it is in fact Kensington Gardens. We were only staying the one night and on the morning of checkout had a little walk around.
