0.title: London through the ages.
0.review: Admission to the main part of the museum is free but there are some exhibitions that you have to pay for.  It has many interesting and educational exhibits and tells the story of London from Neolithic times right up to the modern day. We did a tour around the medieval section which was fascinating.  We saw a reconstructed Anglo-Saxon house and were told about how they lived from day to day in medieval London.  We saw a model of London Bridge, how it looked around King Henry VIIIs reign.  There was some lovely Elizabethan jewellery on display and we learned a lot about the Roman history of London.The museum is well laid out in chronological order with plenty to interest you, with some side attractions such as a Victorian street. It also has an excellent exhibit on the Great Fire of London and you can see part of the original Roman wall here, too. There is a cafe upstairs where we had a nice cuppa and a sandwich and we thought the prices were reasonable.

1.title: An interesting and educational museum.
1.review: We visited the Museum of London again to see some of the artefacts excavated from the Billingsgate Roman Bath House, which we found very interesting.  The Museum is well laid out and the staff were very friendly, enthusiastic and knowledgeable.  There was so much to see and all the artefacts were well labelled.   We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and will probably go again.We enjoyed looking at the row of Victorian shops and there were some fascinating models showing what original buildings looked like before the Fire of London burned them to the ground.  You can also see the remains of the Roman Wall outside the Museum.We had another nice cuppa and a snack in the caf upstairs.

2.title: Beasts of London
2.review: This review is about the paid exhibition "Beasts of London" only. The Museum itself deserves 5 stars and is a must see for families. Beasts of London however I can't recommend and my 8 amd 11 year old were soon bored by the hit and miss nature of the exhibit. Firstly the tickets are timed but we still had to wait 15 minutes in a queue as small groups are let in at 7 minute intervals. You walk from room to room watching a simple animated projection with a voice over each lasting about 10 minutes. The voiceover stretches  five facts to ten minutes by filling with how the animals felt sad at being exploited by humans. This gets old very quickly. The highlight is the apothecary"s room where a realistic apothecary's room full of strange objects, potions and instruments is augmented with projections and instructive video about the plague. The low point is the Roman room where a blank white wall has a simple projection about the Romans menu choices. As I say very hit and miss, mostly miss. One strange gripe, it's difficult to hear the voiceover in some rooms as theres no ceiling on the rooms and no sound insulation so you can clearly hear the next room's audio which is distracting. The worst example is Pigeon where you could barely hear anything and most wandered off to the next room. In fact our group started with about 12 people but only 6 made it to the end.It's annoying because this is a truly great museum and this was a good idea for an exhibition, just poorly executed. Next time let whoever made the apothecary's room make seven of those.

3.title: Another enjoyable visit to the Museum of London.
3.review: This was our third visit to the Museum of London.  This attraction is a must visit if you are in London and its free!The museum was quite busy when we visited this time but we still managed to have a good look round.  I particularly liked the Elizabethan jewellery and the Victorian Street.We had a nice cuppa and a snack in the caf upstairs at reasonable prices.

4.title: Horribly disappointing - i sat down to write this as soon as i got home, i was so upset
4.review: It is some years since I went to St. Pauls and on to the museum, up on London Wall.I had memoires of fascinating and detailed displays, especially those covering Roman and Victorian London.What I found was the now-so-common, dumbed down and children-oriented entertainment" that today passes for a museumChildren are not interested in Museums, from my observations of them - they do not have the intellectual capacity to understand what is being shown and to relate it to what else they know. So why design the whole experience for little people who will not appreciate it or understand it?Kids like to run around museums, noisily, playing with anything which they are allowed to touch (preferably related to swords, dead bodies, etc.) and filling in pointless quizzes which are meant to demonstrate that they have understood what they have seen.sorry, rant over, but adults surely like to visit a museum to see a well-thought out and thought-provoking display of artefacts from each relevant period, not signs which pose questions such as "can you guess why the fire of London spread so quickly?" and to have modern equivalent items (such as painted acrylic fingernails) displayed next to ancient equivalents to show that "we are just the same as our ancestors" - please!I imagine that the museum has a vast store of fascinating material - can we please be allowed to see this, rather than being "entertained" by displays thought out by those who feel that visitors only have the attention span of a newt.Oh and none of the automatic taps in the loos worked - result soapy hands with no way to cleanse them!At least it was free!

5.title: Really disappointed
5.review: As an ex Londoner I visited this museum many times and loved it. .  Having been away from London for years I was really looking forward to revisiting my absolute favourite museum.  It has changed so much and not for the better.It was really sparse - many displays were no longer there (the golden royal coach which even impressed a group of teenagers that I took there when I was a teacher).  It seemed to have a lot of displays that were not london-centric - suffragettes, Andy Pandy on film, Muslim clothing.Didn't see anything about, for example, the dockland area and it's history, hugeonot area of east London and the silk/clothing trade, changing fortunes of what were slum areas and are now sought after, history of and uses of the tower of London, St Bartholomews, the printing industry in Fleet Street, the huge markets that served London and beyond - Smithfield's, covent garden, spitalfields, Billingsgate ....I could go on.Information about where a Roman house was uncovered/assumed to be (?) and the last church to be built in London did not include where they were.A large area has been turned over to a cafe with seating with a bells and whistles screen telling you how happy an area is according to social media - really?I wonder if they've given up on this as they are apparently moving to spitalfields in a couple of years.  I do understand that a museum has limited space etc but -the museum of London- should be about London and not general history that could apply to any other city in the UK.I've told so many people what a fabulous museum this was, not any more.  I look forward to the new site and hope to get there for a visit but I hope it will be a museum of London.

6.title: Walk Through London's History
6.review: The Museum of London happens to be one of my own personal favorites.  I first visited when it opened in 1976 and I have been back several times over the years.  It recently underwent a major refurbishment and its lower galleries just reopened in 2010.The exhibits are set up in linear chronological order and span the years from when aurochs roamed the Thames Valley up to the present, with tourists roaming the much changed landscape.  The arrangement makes it easy to see everything without getting lost or having to backtrack.  If you're interested in how people lived, there's plenty of that including a reconstruction of a Roman dining room, a Saxon hut which you can enter, a Victorian street and even an 18th century prison cell.Just as interesting are the individual objects and articles of clothing.  You can see a bell that was rung during the burials of plague victims.  And a leather helmet that was worn by a 17th century fire fighter battling the Great Fire of London.  Speaking of the Great Fire, there is a very good multimedia presentation that should not be missed.There's an 18th century dress worn by a mayor's daughter that is wider than its height.  The wearer would have had to walk through doorways sideways.  Oliver Cromwell's death mask is in the museum.  So is an unexploded bomb from the blitz.One of my favorites was the splendid gilded Lord Mayor's coach.  I imagined myself riding in it through the streets of London.The museum is adjacent to the ruins of the Roman Wall, which is amazing itself.  It is fully accessible to wheel chairs and has braille panels, free audio guides and objects that can be touched for the visually impaired.Since the collections are always changing, this is a museum that you could visit over and over again and always discover something new and exciting.

7.title: Comprehensive intro to the history London
7.review: One of the lesser known museums in London despite being about the history of London itself.  Rather unattractive on the outside, the museum is a treasure cove of information as it winds from one historical period in the life of the city to another.It starts, slightly repetitively, in pre-historic times with lots of skulls and bones of hippos and wooly rhinos then moving on to a large array of spear and arrow heads.  It gets more interesting with the Romans, displaying some interesting models of Roman London and reproductions of rooms in a Roman-style villa.Coverage of the plague and the great fire lacked imagination I felt, though who would have thought that they tried to treat the plague with toads and chicken bottoms!The museum excels when it comes to more modern times.  The Victorian walk through a variety of shops is excellent.  I also thought that the section on poverty and street life in the 19th and early 20th century was extremely interesting. The most recent decades feel a bit like an afterthought, though I did really enjoy the model of London Fields East "The Ghetto".There is some room for improvement and/or refurbishment in places but overall it's an excellent, interesting and well-structured museum about the life of this city.  Entrance is free.  It's open every day 10am to 6pm.

8.title: confusing and biased
8.review: As a Londoner I have visited many times, but not recently for quite a while. O dear it's gone all politically correct and insidiously left wing concentrating on the poor and non-white migration (once past Elizabethan London.) Which of course is part of London's story but it's rammed down your throat all the time creating a very unbalanced account. There is little proper historical context to the displays and the wealthy and middle classes are almost ignored. There is very little detail given, items are displayed without any explanation with very little details or even identification. There is no mention of Royal London / parks or the development of west/south/north London or builders like Nash or Cubitt. No Hawksmoor or Wren. ( exp. St Pauls) no Whitehall ,Richmond or Nonsuch palace. The golden Lord Mayor's coach has been banished away. No mention of Jewish immigration or of the protestant Huguenots Nothing about the silk weavers of the east end. Nothing about Chinese migration and the Chinese settlements of  Limehouse.  No mention of the Polish air crews and their memorial on the A40. No development of the railways and its impact. Nothing about the underground or real mention of the development of the 1920s/30s suburbs. Nothing about the 1930s 'American' style technically advanced factories along the Western, and Eastern avenues and A10. Nothing about the light industries of the Lea valley. Nothing about the city as a financial centre. Nothing about the canals, lost rivers or London's regeneration. War 1/11 section very, very poor. No indication on how much was destroyed. Nothing about the London's redevelopment post 1945, how was it rebuilt? Nor the housing crisis due to war damage and move of Londoners out to the new towns. And the Disease X exhibition is a joke. But they have managed to fund an artist's model of an imaginary RNA virus ( called mutation without explanation to non scientists how mutation is important). More useful would have been a proper annotated model. Overall a museum for people who don't realise they are being patronised and history being subversively rewritten Overall it is a real disappointment.

9.title: :fire::fire: Fire! Fire! review
9.review: This is a special exhibition about the great fire of London in 1666.  Ends 17 April 2017.  Timed entry so book online if you can, slots every 15 mins, first entry 10am, last entry 4.15pm.  Allow an hour to go round, if you intend to read absolutely everything allow another 15 mins or so.Enough stuff to keep children interested, the dressing up section was popular but I lifted up the leather fireman's hats and they are really heavy!   Take time to look up as you walk in or you will miss the hanging signs etc..  There is a frieze of the timeline of the fire which was a bit counterintuitive for me as you read it right to left.  The information panels throughout give enough info to be interesting and are not so long as to be boring; however I needed a bit more light to be able to read things comfortably.  A feature of the exhibition is that it poses questions eg looking through the microscopes 'What can you see?' - what I needed however were the answers ....Was it worth it?  Well, I'm glad I went.  It was great to be able to look at, and touch, some of the stuff from the great fire but I thought 12 adult entry fee was rather expensive.   Thanks for reading this, if you found it helpful do please tick the box.

0.title: Not as crowded as some of the other museums.
0.review: I particularly liked this museum because it is smaller than the other museums and overlooks the Thames.  It is free, unless you want to go to any of the special exhibitions.There are many galleries to see and there is an excellent array of British works of art from the sixteenth century to modern times.  Everything is in chronological order, which makes it easier to find specific artwork.  There are free guided tours which seemed to be very popular with the visitors.The Turner collection was wonderful and I was not expecting to see so many beautiful paintings in one place.   I cant say I was impressed with some of the items of modern art though, I much prefer the classics.We had tea and cakes in the caf which we enjoyed and there is a nice gift shop where you can buy small items at reasonable prices.

1.title: Britain on show!
1.review: The Tate Britain is one of the four Tate galleries in England, and has to be one of the countrys finest art galleries.  The gallery has certainly had a major impact on the London art scene for more than 100 years, and rightly so as its collection of British art since the 1500s is phenomenal.  The likes of  JMW Turner, John Constable, William Blake and Francis Bacon - the great masters of British painters - and sculptor Henry Moore, are well represented in the gallery, and present a substantial reason for the serious art lover to visit.  But the gallery doesnt shy away from the modern art scene, and the likes of Tracey Emin and Douglas Gordon have their own exhibitions here.  Its an excellent art museum, and one I pop into frequently, especially to see current exhibitions.  Some, like the current  Steve McQueen exhibition, Year 3, are free to visit, as is the  main permanent collection.  Other exhibitions, such as the current William Blake: The Artist exhibition, are not free and are quite expensive to visit (this one is 18.00, with a mediocre 1.00 off for the likes of seniors).  Heres a couple of tips to help you make the most of your visit.1. Check the gallerys website, to make sure its for you.  It focuses on British art, so youre not going to see any of the European masters here.  If thats your aim, youre better off going to the National Gallery at Trafalgar Square. 2. Its  a sprawling gallery, with numerous rooms.  Grab a gallery map, for 1.00, to help you locate the various rooms and installations.3. Photography is permitted, but its important yo be respectful of others, and not to block the best viewing points for interminable periods.4. The gallery will be  very busy on weekends for the next two months or so,  as hordes of children descend upon the gallery to try to find themselves in the Year 3 school photos on display.  But what a fabulously positive  way to introduce youngsters to a gallery! 5. The Turner, Constable and Moore rooms are deservedly popular as they contain extraordinary pieces.  But if youre after JMW Turners most famous painting, The Hay Wain, youll need to head to the National Gallery for that. 6. The gallery is fully accessible for wheelchair users. 7.  On entrance t here's a bag check by security; the less gear you are carrying, the quicker it will be for you.8. Theres two gift shops: one on the main floor and a smaller one on the lower floor.  Theres also a restaurant and a cafe on the lower floor.  There are ample washroom facilities, but all are on the lower floor. The closest underground to the Tate Britain is Pimlico on the Victoria Line.  However, I suggest you take a more scenic route, by alighting at Vauxhall and walking back across the Thames... theres nice views of the river from either side of the Vauxhall Bridge!

2.title: Another enjoyable visit to Tate Britain and its free!
2.review: We popped into this museum again while we were in London to have another wander round.  I wanted to look at the Turner collection again as I had enjoyed it so much on our last visit.The gallery was not as crowded as some of the larger museums in London and there were so many beautiful paintings on display.We had tea and cakes in the caf again followed by a look round the well-stocked gift shop.

3.title: A Bit Disappointed!
3.review: I must admit that I was a bit disappointed by the the Tate Britain. The building's interior lacks the warmth of the V & A or the beauty of the National Gallery. The collections of English art are very good, but some of the works are in obvious need of cleaning or restoration. The Tate shop can't compare to the V & A or the British Museum shops. I would rank the Tate Britain behind the National Gallery, the British Museum, The V & A and the British Library in terms of cultural attractions. Plan to spend no more than 90 minutes here - unless you have a special interest in English art.

4.title: Brilliant Turner exhibition
4.review: The Tate never lets you down! As a Turner fan this latest exhibition is a must see and the whole Tate experience is one to be treasured.

5.title: William Blake exhibition
5.review: I strongly recommend to visit this special eventI have finally seen other works of Blake that I have never been able to see beforeComplete and accurate ,the layout impressive Also what a better place to see William Blake art if not in his own town?!It worth every penny

6.title: Great way to spend a Sunday
6.review: We visited on a Sunday and luckily it wasn't very busy. Considering this is a free attraction, we were really impressed with the displays and more so by the wonderful group tour of the archives with the mother & daughter team of Jess & Sue. They are amazing storytellers and we learnt loads about the history of the tate and some of its renowned works. Highly recommend!

7.title: Great Place to see British Art (for free), plus the Hockney Exhibition
7.review: You need to spend about 17.50 for a ticket to the David Hockney Exhibition. After you purchase your timed ticket (entry to the exhibition itself is about 30 minutes later on a weekday), I suggest that you look at as many of the permanent exhibitions as you can (on the same floor) rather than stand in a queue waiting for your entry time.  If you, for example, have a 12 noon ticket, either go to the queue about 10 minutes before 12 to get in reasonably quickly or wait until 12:15 (since by then the queue will usually have disappeared and you can always stay in the Exhibition longer than 1230).  It takes at least 30 minutes to see the Hockney exhibition, but better to allow yourself 1 - 2 hours if you want to read the useful free Hockney booklet while going from room to room (or take one of the audio guides). There are small crowds, but not sufficient to prevent you from getting close to all of the works. The exhibits start in the early 1960s and go to the present, and feature both his Yorkshire and California artworks.I find his work a combination of contradictions: blazing lively colours, yet the people in the paintings seem frozen, almost lifeless, with expressionless faces.  At times, he creates depth and perspective, as in Going Up Garrowby Hill, yet the painting is also strangely vertical, like The Rubber Ring Floating in a Swimming Pool.  As his work develops to embrace art created from new technology like iPhones and iPads, it can also display continuity, like the paintings of red pots on the balcony of his garden (2006) and then again in 2016.  I particularly liked his 4 seasons montage done by video cameras shot over time.   Nature stands still, and only the camera moves, creating a meditative, hypnotic effect on the viewer.  Definitely go to this Exhibition, but also allow time to see the other great works of art on display at Tate Britain.

8.title: Total Rubbish - Modern dsiplay is for shock value not art
8.review: Tate Modern is one of the worst art exhibits I have ever scene anywhere in the world.  I do not call piles of crap art.  Nor do I call the barb wire and torture chamber displays art.  The 3 of us hated almost everything in it.  Most of the modern stuff is what I call anti Christ or protest art with negativity andshock value ( like having real piles of crap on display) more than anything resembling art.  Do not waste your time or effort to go here

9.title: New members room not a room more of a hallway
9.review: As a member of some years I was surprised at all the praise about the New Tate Britain Members Room which is not a room at all. It is not even a private area as any member of the public can walk through it and buy food and drink without ever being asked if they are a member. Proper members rooms are like the V&A or the Tate Modern which are private areas where members can relax over some food, wine or coffee with other members. I think I will lapse this membership and stick to my memberships that have a proper members room as for me considering all the main museums and art galleries are free there seem little point in being a member if you don't have a proper members room.

30.title: London through the ages.
30.review: Admission to the main part of the museum is free but there are some exhibitions that you have to pay for.  It has many interesting and educational exhibits and tells the story of London from Neolithic times right up to the modern day. We did a tour around the medieval section which was fascinating.  We saw a reconstructed Anglo-Saxon house and were told about how they lived from day to day in medieval London.  We saw a model of London Bridge, how it looked around King Henry VIIIs reign.  There was some lovely Elizabethan jewellery on display and we learned a lot about the Roman history of London.The museum is well laid out in chronological order with plenty to interest you, with some side attractions such as a Victorian street. It also has an excellent exhibit on the Great Fire of London and you can see part of the original Roman wall here, too. There is a cafe upstairs where we had a nice cuppa and a sandwich and we thought the prices were reasonable.

31.title: An interesting and educational museum.
31.review: We visited the Museum of London again to see some of the artefacts excavated from the Billingsgate Roman Bath House, which we found very interesting.  The Museum is well laid out and the staff were very friendly, enthusiastic and knowledgeable.  There was so much to see and all the artefacts were well labelled.   We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and will probably go again.We enjoyed looking at the row of Victorian shops and there were some fascinating models showing what original buildings looked like before the Fire of London burned them to the ground.  You can also see the remains of the Roman Wall outside the Museum.We had another nice cuppa and a snack in the caf upstairs.

32.title: Beasts of London
32.review: This review is about the paid exhibition "Beasts of London" only. The Museum itself deserves 5 stars and is a must see for families. Beasts of London however I can't recommend and my 8 amd 11 year old were soon bored by the hit and miss nature of the exhibit. Firstly the tickets are timed but we still had to wait 15 minutes in a queue as small groups are let in at 7 minute intervals. You walk from room to room watching a simple animated projection with a voice over each lasting about 10 minutes. The voiceover stretches  five facts to ten minutes by filling with how the animals felt sad at being exploited by humans. This gets old very quickly. The highlight is the apothecary"s room where a realistic apothecary's room full of strange objects, potions and instruments is augmented with projections and instructive video about the plague. The low point is the Roman room where a blank white wall has a simple projection about the Romans menu choices. As I say very hit and miss, mostly miss. One strange gripe, it's difficult to hear the voiceover in some rooms as theres no ceiling on the rooms and no sound insulation so you can clearly hear the next room's audio which is distracting. The worst example is Pigeon where you could barely hear anything and most wandered off to the next room. In fact our group started with about 12 people but only 6 made it to the end.It's annoying because this is a truly great museum and this was a good idea for an exhibition, just poorly executed. Next time let whoever made the apothecary's room make seven of those.

33.title: Another enjoyable visit to the Museum of London.
33.review: This was our third visit to the Museum of London.  This attraction is a must visit if you are in London and its free!The museum was quite busy when we visited this time but we still managed to have a good look round.  I particularly liked the Elizabethan jewellery and the Victorian Street.We had a nice cuppa and a snack in the caf upstairs at reasonable prices.

34.title: Horribly disappointing - i sat down to write this as soon as i got home, i was so upset
34.review: It is some years since I went to St. Pauls and on to the museum, up on London Wall.I had memoires of fascinating and detailed displays, especially those covering Roman and Victorian London.What I found was the now-so-common, dumbed down and children-oriented entertainment" that today passes for a museumChildren are not interested in Museums, from my observations of them - they do not have the intellectual capacity to understand what is being shown and to relate it to what else they know. So why design the whole experience for little people who will not appreciate it or understand it?Kids like to run around museums, noisily, playing with anything which they are allowed to touch (preferably related to swords, dead bodies, etc.) and filling in pointless quizzes which are meant to demonstrate that they have understood what they have seen.sorry, rant over, but adults surely like to visit a museum to see a well-thought out and thought-provoking display of artefacts from each relevant period, not signs which pose questions such as "can you guess why the fire of London spread so quickly?" and to have modern equivalent items (such as painted acrylic fingernails) displayed next to ancient equivalents to show that "we are just the same as our ancestors" - please!I imagine that the museum has a vast store of fascinating material - can we please be allowed to see this, rather than being "entertained" by displays thought out by those who feel that visitors only have the attention span of a newt.Oh and none of the automatic taps in the loos worked - result soapy hands with no way to cleanse them!At least it was free!

35.title: Really disappointed
35.review: As an ex Londoner I visited this museum many times and loved it. .  Having been away from London for years I was really looking forward to revisiting my absolute favourite museum.  It has changed so much and not for the better.It was really sparse - many displays were no longer there (the golden royal coach which even impressed a group of teenagers that I took there when I was a teacher).  It seemed to have a lot of displays that were not london-centric - suffragettes, Andy Pandy on film, Muslim clothing.Didn't see anything about, for example, the dockland area and it's history, hugeonot area of east London and the silk/clothing trade, changing fortunes of what were slum areas and are now sought after, history of and uses of the tower of London, St Bartholomews, the printing industry in Fleet Street, the huge markets that served London and beyond - Smithfield's, covent garden, spitalfields, Billingsgate ....I could go on.Information about where a Roman house was uncovered/assumed to be (?) and the last church to be built in London did not include where they were.A large area has been turned over to a cafe with seating with a bells and whistles screen telling you how happy an area is according to social media - really?I wonder if they've given up on this as they are apparently moving to spitalfields in a couple of years.  I do understand that a museum has limited space etc but -the museum of London- should be about London and not general history that could apply to any other city in the UK.I've told so many people what a fabulous museum this was, not any more.  I look forward to the new site and hope to get there for a visit but I hope it will be a museum of London.

36.title: Walk Through London's History
36.review: The Museum of London happens to be one of my own personal favorites.  I first visited when it opened in 1976 and I have been back several times over the years.  It recently underwent a major refurbishment and its lower galleries just reopened in 2010.The exhibits are set up in linear chronological order and span the years from when aurochs roamed the Thames Valley up to the present, with tourists roaming the much changed landscape.  The arrangement makes it easy to see everything without getting lost or having to backtrack.  If you're interested in how people lived, there's plenty of that including a reconstruction of a Roman dining room, a Saxon hut which you can enter, a Victorian street and even an 18th century prison cell.Just as interesting are the individual objects and articles of clothing.  You can see a bell that was rung during the burials of plague victims.  And a leather helmet that was worn by a 17th century fire fighter battling the Great Fire of London.  Speaking of the Great Fire, there is a very good multimedia presentation that should not be missed.There's an 18th century dress worn by a mayor's daughter that is wider than its height.  The wearer would have had to walk through doorways sideways.  Oliver Cromwell's death mask is in the museum.  So is an unexploded bomb from the blitz.One of my favorites was the splendid gilded Lord Mayor's coach.  I imagined myself riding in it through the streets of London.The museum is adjacent to the ruins of the Roman Wall, which is amazing itself.  It is fully accessible to wheel chairs and has braille panels, free audio guides and objects that can be touched for the visually impaired.Since the collections are always changing, this is a museum that you could visit over and over again and always discover something new and exciting.

37.title: Comprehensive intro to the history London
37.review: One of the lesser known museums in London despite being about the history of London itself.  Rather unattractive on the outside, the museum is a treasure cove of information as it winds from one historical period in the life of the city to another.It starts, slightly repetitively, in pre-historic times with lots of skulls and bones of hippos and wooly rhinos then moving on to a large array of spear and arrow heads.  It gets more interesting with the Romans, displaying some interesting models of Roman London and reproductions of rooms in a Roman-style villa.Coverage of the plague and the great fire lacked imagination I felt, though who would have thought that they tried to treat the plague with toads and chicken bottoms!The museum excels when it comes to more modern times.  The Victorian walk through a variety of shops is excellent.  I also thought that the section on poverty and street life in the 19th and early 20th century was extremely interesting. The most recent decades feel a bit like an afterthought, though I did really enjoy the model of London Fields East "The Ghetto".There is some room for improvement and/or refurbishment in places but overall it's an excellent, interesting and well-structured museum about the life of this city.  Entrance is free.  It's open every day 10am to 6pm.

38.title: confusing and biased
38.review: As a Londoner I have visited many times, but not recently for quite a while. O dear it's gone all politically correct and insidiously left wing concentrating on the poor and non-white migration (once past Elizabethan London.) Which of course is part of London's story but it's rammed down your throat all the time creating a very unbalanced account. There is little proper historical context to the displays and the wealthy and middle classes are almost ignored. There is very little detail given, items are displayed without any explanation with very little details or even identification. There is no mention of Royal London / parks or the development of west/south/north London or builders like Nash or Cubitt. No Hawksmoor or Wren. ( exp. St Pauls) no Whitehall ,Richmond or Nonsuch palace. The golden Lord Mayor's coach has been banished away. No mention of Jewish immigration or of the protestant Huguenots Nothing about the silk weavers of the east end. Nothing about Chinese migration and the Chinese settlements of  Limehouse.  No mention of the Polish air crews and their memorial on the A40. No development of the railways and its impact. Nothing about the underground or real mention of the development of the 1920s/30s suburbs. Nothing about the 1930s 'American' style technically advanced factories along the Western, and Eastern avenues and A10. Nothing about the light industries of the Lea valley. Nothing about the city as a financial centre. Nothing about the canals, lost rivers or London's regeneration. War 1/11 section very, very poor. No indication on how much was destroyed. Nothing about the London's redevelopment post 1945, how was it rebuilt? Nor the housing crisis due to war damage and move of Londoners out to the new towns. And the Disease X exhibition is a joke. But they have managed to fund an artist's model of an imaginary RNA virus ( called mutation without explanation to non scientists how mutation is important). More useful would have been a proper annotated model. Overall a museum for people who don't realise they are being patronised and history being subversively rewritten Overall it is a real disappointment.

39.title: :fire::fire: Fire! Fire! review
39.review: This is a special exhibition about the great fire of London in 1666.  Ends 17 April 2017.  Timed entry so book online if you can, slots every 15 mins, first entry 10am, last entry 4.15pm.  Allow an hour to go round, if you intend to read absolutely everything allow another 15 mins or so.Enough stuff to keep children interested, the dressing up section was popular but I lifted up the leather fireman's hats and they are really heavy!   Take time to look up as you walk in or you will miss the hanging signs etc..  There is a frieze of the timeline of the fire which was a bit counterintuitive for me as you read it right to left.  The information panels throughout give enough info to be interesting and are not so long as to be boring; however I needed a bit more light to be able to read things comfortably.  A feature of the exhibition is that it poses questions eg looking through the microscopes 'What can you see?' - what I needed however were the answers ....Was it worth it?  Well, I'm glad I went.  It was great to be able to look at, and touch, some of the stuff from the great fire but I thought 12 adult entry fee was rather expensive.   Thanks for reading this, if you found it helpful do please tick the box.

30.title: Splendid park
30.review: Kensington Gardens is the park next to Hyde park and if you explore one you should explore the other, lot of paths to wander and beautiful Italian gardens, fountains and statues like the two bears and Peter Pan.

31.title: Beautiful with a calming vibe.
31.review: I have basically grown up going here living very close. I love it here particularly around the pound and watching the birds. Its so beautiful going around the palace and have a connection to nature. For younger kids, the Princess Diana Playground is perfect, however almost always busy so you must keep a very close eye of your child. For anyone, I would really recommend a trip if you live in London or staying here. You can also find many facilities around the park like one of my fave the ice skating rink in the winter then a nice walk in the park!

32.title: The gardens are free and beautiful
32.review: A beautiful garden to spend a few hours , you can access them without going to the place and when the place is open you will also have access to the sunken gardens

33.title: A quieter more natural experience
33.review: On the other side of the bridge from Hyde Park, you can enjoy a more peaceful, more natural park. The criss crossing paths make it feel almost private at times but with occasional monuments, statues and stop points, theres plenty to look at.

34.title: Great drama
34.review: Love this park for ages :smiling_face_with_heart-eyes: so romantic for all in London Town in this era of the pandemic  and  brexit

35.title: Fantastic Garden with park and Swans in lake. It's so soothing
35.review: One of the largest gardens in central London. Spacious green area and plenty walking paths. Can be crowded during weekends and holidays, which, in a way,is testimony for its popularity.

36.title: Perfect for a walk
36.review: I came here with a friend to eat our sandwiches on one of the many benches. We had a delightful walk and the park is large enough to easily maintain social distancing.

37.title: Princess Diana Dresses
37.review: I Love Royalty!!!!So much to see Wimbledon on next tripWe need to be blessed and vaccines working for allComing back soon.  I promise. Louise and Keith

38.title: Lovely park!
38.review: Plenty of green space with Round Water in front of Kensington Palace. Saw a black swan in the water. Theres a Dianas memorial playground for kids. Great place for a stroll. Theres a cafe by the Palace too and plenty of open air seating.

39.title: A little stroll
39.review: December 2019 Myself and my partner were staying over the road from here at the Hilton Hyde Park so we assumed this was part of Hyde Park but we found that it is in fact Kensington Gardens. We were only staying the one night and on the morning of checkout had a little walk around. It was a bright cold day and it was lovely to take a stroll around heading to the lake and towards the palace. A nice little visit I think we only saw a small part of it but what we did see was a well kept park with some wildlife such as swans and squirrels.

0.title: Ok
0.review: Okish tour in North London and good shop mind and cafes nearby and maybe the shop was somewhere else come to think of it good :thumbs_up: history

1.title: Outstanding Staff
1.review: We took my husband for a tour for Fathers Day and it was brilliant. Even my oldest daughter who doesnt like football had a great time. The stadium is amazing but what made the whole visit for us was the staff, every single one of them were passionate, knowledgeable and cheerful. Even the staff in the shop were excellent, nothing was too much trouble.  We will definitely be returning, hopefully for a match day. Thank you Emirates! :smiling_face_with_heart-eyes:

2.title: Crackin day out
2.review: The misses treated me to a day out in London and arranged for us to go to stadium and it was a good sight to behold

3.title: Matchday - great stadium
3.review: Great stadium with great atmosphere.Professional security.Good selection of food and drinks and easy access to facilities. Managed to attend one game on the Club Level of the stadium which highlight club history and has an even more extensive range of food and drinks options.

4.title: Good tour even for non-Gunners fans
4.review: As a big football fan I really enjoyed this tour of the Emirates. It was an audio guide so no in person guide but it was great to see behind the scenes and learn about the history of the club even as a Man Utd fan haha!

5.title: Tour is very worth it
5.review: When visiting London I came with my brother that is an Arsenal fan (I am a United fan) to do a tour of the stadium. It really was very cool to see the locker room where the players get ready and all the behind the scenes stuff. It truly is one of the lost beautiful stadiums in the world. It was also awesome to visit the museum after the tour to see years of football history. If there isnt a game while youre in town I highly recommend the tour. Im sure its almost as good as a tour of Old Trafford :winking_face:

6.title: Organised tour
6.review: Nice tour, still takes place during the pandemic period. You will be asked to wear your own mask. The standsrd price for the tour is 25. You will be giving wipes to clean the seats if you want to seat down and enjoy the stands. The tour is an audio tour, not with a guide. Which is available in English, Italian, Portuguese, French, Nederlands, Japanese, Spanish, German, Chinese and British Sign Language. No parking available at facilities. But friendly staff. You will be given a free certificate for attending a tour. Also, you can take some pictures on a green screen. Minimum price is 15.

7.title: Excellent day out!
7.review: Not an Arsenal fan, but was very happy to see the stadium, learn a lot about its grand history, feel the energy and be a part of this experience. It was lots of fun.Once we finished the tour, my daughter told me the following: 'Daddy, now I know about football and stadiums, when the boys are talking about it at school, I can say few things I learnt.'

8.title: OK
8.review: Was here. Only thing I would change if someone goes with you and talkes with you on the tour. We had time for everything but the museum didnt work and thats the only flaw because we payed ticket for both.

9.title: Excellent
9.review: Great stadium with great atmosphere. Have never been to a Premier League match with the same enthusiasm as the Emirates. Would highly recommend.

30.title: New chronological hanging simply superb! 'Meet British Art' a fabulous event
30.review: The new hanging by chronological time period - as per the new Louvre in Lens, France - is just excellent. So refreshing to see in this way. And of course there are still separate rooms - like the Turner room - for major artists.The current 'Meet British Art' has some amazingly good pieces (see my pics attached) - in particular I adore the Henry Moore sculptures, and various portraits by Lucian Freud.A must-see. British art at its best.

31.title: Snobby staff can't handle on-line bookings
31.review: Such a shame, the staff had a snooty attitude and did not know their own systems. I won't be going back.I planned a 'Tate Day' going to the Tate Britain in the morning, taking the Tate Boat to the Tate Modern for a guided tour of a special exhibtion in the afternoon. In preparation for this I booked a boat ticket and guided tour ticket on-line.Arriving at the Tate Britain in the morning, I was told that to collect  pre-booked, pre-paid tickets I had to wait in the 30-minute queue with those who were simply buying tickets on the day (so what benefit to booking in advance?!). When I finally arrived at the top of the queue, the sales assistant told me that all tickets (including for the boat) are held for collection at the Tate Modern instead! What a waste of my time.So I was booked and paid-up to get to my destination (Tate Modern) by boat, but to board the boat I needed a ticket - which apparently I couldn't get until my destination. Conundrum!The only option was to walk to the Modern (45 mins at a brisk pace, thankfully in fine weather) where they told me that of course the Britain could have issued the boat ticket. They happily refunded my boat fare as by that time it would have been impossible to have the boat ride as well as make the guided tour.My advice to others:- Don't bother to book tickets on-line, there is no apparent benefit (unless you want to get tickets to a popular exhibition which might be sold-out)- Go to the Tate Modern in preference to the Britain as the staff there seemed much more knowledgeable and had a more helpful attitude. If you have time to pop down to the Britain after you are finished with the Modern, it might be worth considering.

32.title: Also disappointed
32.review: After hearing Tate Britain this, Tate Britain that, I really had high expectations.  But upon arrival, I was asking myself if I was in the wrong building!  First of all, it was very isolated from most of London attractions.  Not easy to find or to get to.  The staff strutted around in black t-shirts, acting like a bunch of pretentious hairstylists.  I ended up asking a janitor questions about a specific painting because the staff hadn't a clue!There were definitely some beautiful works of art, but the tone of the environment left a bad taste in my mouth.  I'll probably never waste my time there again as there are so many other great places to visit in London.

33.title: Disappointed
33.review: Until I left London 25 years ago I visited this place every two weeks. Back then I spent hours there. I am back for the first time in 25 years and was disappointed. Lots of rooms with just blue tack! Is it me or has the size shrunk. Didn't help that on my first time back, the painting I had grown up loving wasn't even there! Not sure I would make the effort to visit again in the next 25 years. What used to take me at least half a day to admire the art, took me 15 minutes. Disappointing for me and also for my children who I had hyped the place up to!

34.title: Plan enough time
34.review: I came here directly from Tate Modern by boat - which I can recommend to everyone, it's such a great and fresh view on the city from the water level.It was the first time at Tate Britain and I was immediately impressed by the building. I hadn't planned for a long visit - and I regretted it - but it gives me an excuse to come back.The collection is amazing. Plan to spend plenty of time.

35.title: If you only visit one gallery, make it this one
35.review: There is something for everyone here and aside from the extensive Turner Collection, (heaven if you love Turner), there is a diverse collection of art and sculpture organised by time period from 1540 to present day. Even in the rooms where the art is "not your thing" it is likely you'll find at least one picture or sculpture that will engage your interest. Sadly, Surrealism is unrepresented here - I believe you have to visit the Tate Modern for that, but there is more than enough to compensate. I was surprised by how quiet this place was for a Saturday afternoon in the height of the tourist season. We spent about 3 hours here and could have easily spent longer, but needed to eat. (There is a cafe which we didn't visit as we had other plans). Sadly, we just missed the Van Gogh exhibition, which I only found out about on the last day, so only toured the free galleries. There is a William Blake exhibition opening in September so I will be back.

36.title: Van Gogh - finally I can see!
36.review: You expect good content at the top London galleries, but of late many have been so packed that you can't see past the other visitors. The Tate seems to have handled the numbers allowed in per slot well to give you time and space to enjoy the pictures and the information. The story is well told with supporting materials. I would definitely recommend the audio accompaniment.

37.title: Van Gogh Exhibition
37.review: I came specifically for the Van Gogh Exhibition whilst on a trip, booked the trip around it really as Im a huge fan of Van Gogh. The exhibition was very vast, had a lot of quotes and history throughout. It was breathtaking and moving exhibition. Very well done. I took the extra time to see the other exhibitions and works of art, and all were very good. I was actually surprised how much I liked the other artists as well, as they are completely different than my favourite Van Gogh. The building itself is very large and clean. I highly recommend visiting here!

38.title: Amazing, super full day
38.review: There is so much to see and enjoy that you really need to plan your day. We went to see the Van Gogh exhibit and then enjoyed exploring all the other rooms. Wish we could have had more time, I feel like we only scratched the surface

39.title: Fantastic!
39.review: I had wanted to visit the Tate Britain for many years but whenever I came to London with family or friends no one else wanted to! So I cane down to London on my own!I used the underground and got out at Pimlico which was perfect and only a few hundred yards from the gallery. When exiting from the underground the Tate was well signposted, and the intro/exit tunnel had famous paintings set into the wall tiles which was a nice touch.The security staff who searched my bag were very friendly.I started by having a cake and tea in the basement cafe. As with any museum or gallery you know you will pay a bit more than a street cafe, but the food and drink were fine, and there was free wifi.I bought a map for 1 and started what was to be a three hour walk round. I got lost a few times and found myself doubling back on some paintings but that was down to me not the map!All I can say is 'Wow'! What a fantastic collection of paintings, many I had seen in books, and recently I have been watching the Tate Walks on Sky Art, and to be able to see these paintings up close and photograph them was special.Every British painter was represented and my favourites were the many pre-raphaelite paintings.I will make every effort to come back here as soon as I can.

20.title: The Crime Museum Uncovered
20.review: For this particular exhibition at the Museum of London it cost 12 per person, and once there we seriously considered demanding our money back.Granted, it was the first day it was open and was thus sure to be busy, but so many people were crammed into it that one could barely move.A friend described it as like waiting in a queue for a theme park ride, and that's exactly how it was, but sadly throughout the entire trip - slow moving and cramped. It was so crowded one couldn't deviate at all! The museum really needs to review the number of people they let in at any one time, as there were far too many.Also, for the amount of money paid, the exhibition was far too small. Yes, there were some interesting artifacts on display, but only two people at a time could look at them, and the exhibition itself was tiny. I think a price of 5 at most would be sufficient. There also needed to be much more literature rather than a simple 'blurb' for each item on display - this is a museum, after all!Lastly, there seemed to be no air conditioning, and with so many people in there it was not a pleasant place to be - by the end we gave up and left without watching the video.There are other parts of the museum that are fascinating, and the staff are friendly, hence two stars rather than one, but I really think that for this particular exhibition, something that could have been a great asset has instead been a major disappointment.Oh, and the automatic taps in the toilets didn't work either!

21.title: Beasts of London a tad underwhelming
21.review: Despite living nearby, this was my first time in the Museum of London. The museum itself was amazing, if only Id left myself more time to explore it in its entirety. The Beasts of London exhibit was a whim decision - it looked really interesting - but I came away a little underwhelmed. I felt there was a heavy emphasis on children with little to entertain and inform any older visitors. It could have benefited from some of the darker stories London has to offer (without any comedic voice acting), such as the case of Jacco Macacco, the London bear baiting craze, and the fate of Chunee the elephant (I assumed the elephant on the poster was an allusion to his story). If its an exhibit primarily for kids, a notice to that effect would have been helpful. Ill definitely be back to explore the museum some more, but a topic like Londons animal history could be a great deal more universally presented.

22.title: Dont waste your money on The Beasts of London
22.review: We were looking forward to seeing The Beasts of London. As a family this cost 30. The trailer on the web looks exciting and immersive. This is definitely not what it is! You walk from room to room with projections of animals on the walls you can hardly see, with a narration which is barely audible as all the sounds are coming through from other rooms. It definitely felt like going back in time cinematically, not in a good way. Totally boring and a waste of money!

23.title: The Beasts of London
23.review: Quite disappointed. Poor animation, not clear sounds, the information is presented in a boring way. For a paid attraction the expectations are higher. We wont be coming back. The rest of museum is fine. Expensive item in the shop.

24.title: Excellent Museum
24.review: Its slightly of the beaten track but easily reachable by tube, and its free. We only had time to do the gallery from the Great fire of London to present day but it was well worth. Some great exhibits and plenty of time required to do it justice, give a donation on your way out.

25.title: A gem of a museum in a city filled with museums!
25.review: I have visited London many times, and have visited all those big, famous museums - the Tate, the V&A, the Natural History Museum, etc etc. For some reason, I hadn't ever made it over to the Museum of London! What an error! It should absolutely be on your list of Must-See museums when you visit! The museum presents a full history of London, from prehistoric times to the present, and is a super interactive, fun place. One of the many highlights includes a small recreation of a Victorian-era street - great photo ops abound! It is also very close to the old London Wall, which is just steps away from the museum (you can see a portion of it from inside the museum too) and also worth a visit. When planning your London itinerary, may I recommend breakfast at the London Wall restaurant, which is just next door to the Museum of London (They serve a full English breakfast!) followed by at least 2 hours at the museum, about 20-30 minutes to explore the London Wall (the actual wall, not the restaurant!) outside, and then maybe pop on over to St. Paul's Cathedral, which is just down the road.

26.title: Beasts of London paid 'Exhibition'
26.review: Incredibly disappointed. Expected an exhibition featuring brewery dray horses, Downing Street cat, cockfight playbills, inspired pottery...  Received tiny areas showing poorly animated, poor quality films which were loud, overpowered each other and on occassion made you feel unwell. Possibly, this exhibition would be more acceptable if it claimed to be directed only at children but lacked sufficient clarity or content to continuously entertain them (certainly not the child visiting at the same time). We left the area after ten minutes.Very few artefacts (told there was 1.5minutes betwween zoned films in which to look at displays).. More would have been achieved if the films were edited into one continuous showing using a room that could accomodate them. However, that would not have repaired the rump of the black horse on The Mall!No explanation of the format was given until the entrance was reached. I would have preferred to pay an entrance fee for the museum than feel misled into paying to see this 'spectacle'. The best thing about it were the foyer ads.Incidentally, lower cafe had a cream tea offer but tea machine broken so sent us to lobby cafe. It had tea but no scones! Explained and suggested that perhaps they could be transferred from downstairs.Didn't happen.I enjoyed the Musuem many years ago when it focussed on the vibrant history of London (not the far Thames Valley). Today even the Great Fire of London model was static/broken?

27.title: Disappointed latest exhibition
27.review: I've always thought the activities thrown by Museum of London were good in the past hence why I did not hesitate to book the Beast of London for a family of 4.However, I was quite disappointed.  Children moved from one 'room' to another to listen to some narration with poor acoustics with some animation.  At one point, it wasn't clear that the giant pigeon was also a 'room' too which I think threw other guests too as by the time I entered the last room, other guests other than those in our group joined us making it even more difficult to engage there.Considering how much we paid, I was expecting a lot more interaction...

28.title: Beasts of London
28.review: Absolutely awful, don't bother wasting your money just a bunch of moving pictures that makes you feel sick. Also glamourizes circus industry and bating. Teaches kids that animals are brought over to abuse and use for whatever purposes we want. Really short about 20 mins and honesty have no idea what main message or point was.

29.title: A wonderful surprise :)
29.review: Perhaps I'm a history geek, but I just had so much fun in this museum. Seeing that I didn't even have to pay for those two delightful hours, I've felt the urge to review this museum. It basically tells the story of London from the pre-historic times to the modern day. The museum is large and well kept. The exhibitions are vast and interesting. There's even a part where you can walk through the streets of London during the Victorian period, which was so fun for me (so i'm guessing young children would probably enjoy that even more). All in all, as a tourist who learnt only about the imperial period of Britain and world wars, I was very excited to learn and see there's so much more to the history of this beautiful city. Do yourselves a favour and visit!

20.title: New chronological hanging simply superb! 'Meet British Art' a fabulous event
20.review: The new hanging by chronological time period - as per the new Louvre in Lens, France - is just excellent. So refreshing to see in this way. And of course there are still separate rooms - like the Turner room - for major artists.The current 'Meet British Art' has some amazingly good pieces (see my pics attached) - in particular I adore the Henry Moore sculptures, and various portraits by Lucian Freud.A must-see. British art at its best.

21.title: Snobby staff can't handle on-line bookings
21.review: Such a shame, the staff had a snooty attitude and did not know their own systems. I won't be going back.I planned a 'Tate Day' going to the Tate Britain in the morning, taking the Tate Boat to the Tate Modern for a guided tour of a special exhibtion in the afternoon. In preparation for this I booked a boat ticket and guided tour ticket on-line.Arriving at the Tate Britain in the morning, I was told that to collect  pre-booked, pre-paid tickets I had to wait in the 30-minute queue with those who were simply buying tickets on the day (so what benefit to booking in advance?!). When I finally arrived at the top of the queue, the sales assistant told me that all tickets (including for the boat) are held for collection at the Tate Modern instead! What a waste of my time.So I was booked and paid-up to get to my destination (Tate Modern) by boat, but to board the boat I needed a ticket - which apparently I couldn't get until my destination. Conundrum!The only option was to walk to the Modern (45 mins at a brisk pace, thankfully in fine weather) where they told me that of course the Britain could have issued the boat ticket. They happily refunded my boat fare as by that time it would have been impossible to have the boat ride as well as make the guided tour.My advice to others:- Don't bother to book tickets on-line, there is no apparent benefit (unless you want to get tickets to a popular exhibition which might be sold-out)- Go to the Tate Modern in preference to the Britain as the staff there seemed much more knowledgeable and had a more helpful attitude. If you have time to pop down to the Britain after you are finished with the Modern, it might be worth considering.

22.title: Also disappointed
22.review: After hearing Tate Britain this, Tate Britain that, I really had high expectations.  But upon arrival, I was asking myself if I was in the wrong building!  First of all, it was very isolated from most of London attractions.  Not easy to find or to get to.  The staff strutted around in black t-shirts, acting like a bunch of pretentious hairstylists.  I ended up asking a janitor questions about a specific painting because the staff hadn't a clue!There were definitely some beautiful works of art, but the tone of the environment left a bad taste in my mouth.  I'll probably never waste my time there again as there are so many other great places to visit in London.

23.title: Disappointed
23.review: Until I left London 25 years ago I visited this place every two weeks. Back then I spent hours there. I am back for the first time in 25 years and was disappointed. Lots of rooms with just blue tack! Is it me or has the size shrunk. Didn't help that on my first time back, the painting I had grown up loving wasn't even there! Not sure I would make the effort to visit again in the next 25 years. What used to take me at least half a day to admire the art, took me 15 minutes. Disappointing for me and also for my children who I had hyped the place up to!

24.title: Plan enough time
24.review: I came here directly from Tate Modern by boat - which I can recommend to everyone, it's such a great and fresh view on the city from the water level.It was the first time at Tate Britain and I was immediately impressed by the building. I hadn't planned for a long visit - and I regretted it - but it gives me an excuse to come back.The collection is amazing. Plan to spend plenty of time.

25.title: If you only visit one gallery, make it this one
25.review: There is something for everyone here and aside from the extensive Turner Collection, (heaven if you love Turner), there is a diverse collection of art and sculpture organised by time period from 1540 to present day. Even in the rooms where the art is "not your thing" it is likely you'll find at least one picture or sculpture that will engage your interest. Sadly, Surrealism is unrepresented here - I believe you have to visit the Tate Modern for that, but there is more than enough to compensate. I was surprised by how quiet this place was for a Saturday afternoon in the height of the tourist season. We spent about 3 hours here and could have easily spent longer, but needed to eat. (There is a cafe which we didn't visit as we had other plans). Sadly, we just missed the Van Gogh exhibition, which I only found out about on the last day, so only toured the free galleries. There is a William Blake exhibition opening in September so I will be back.

26.title: Van Gogh - finally I can see!
26.review: You expect good content at the top London galleries, but of late many have been so packed that you can't see past the other visitors. The Tate seems to have handled the numbers allowed in per slot well to give you time and space to enjoy the pictures and the information. The story is well told with supporting materials. I would definitely recommend the audio accompaniment.

27.title: Van Gogh Exhibition
27.review: I came specifically for the Van Gogh Exhibition whilst on a trip, booked the trip around it really as Im a huge fan of Van Gogh. The exhibition was very vast, had a lot of quotes and history throughout. It was breathtaking and moving exhibition. Very well done. I took the extra time to see the other exhibitions and works of art, and all were very good. I was actually surprised how much I liked the other artists as well, as they are completely different than my favourite Van Gogh. The building itself is very large and clean. I highly recommend visiting here!

28.title: Amazing, super full day
28.review: There is so much to see and enjoy that you really need to plan your day. We went to see the Van Gogh exhibit and then enjoyed exploring all the other rooms. Wish we could have had more time, I feel like we only scratched the surface

29.title: Fantastic!
29.review: I had wanted to visit the Tate Britain for many years but whenever I came to London with family or friends no one else wanted to! So I cane down to London on my own!I used the underground and got out at Pimlico which was perfect and only a few hundred yards from the gallery. When exiting from the underground the Tate was well signposted, and the intro/exit tunnel had famous paintings set into the wall tiles which was a nice touch.The security staff who searched my bag were very friendly.I started by having a cake and tea in the basement cafe. As with any museum or gallery you know you will pay a bit more than a street cafe, but the food and drink were fine, and there was free wifi.I bought a map for 1 and started what was to be a three hour walk round. I got lost a few times and found myself doubling back on some paintings but that was down to me not the map!All I can say is 'Wow'! What a fantastic collection of paintings, many I had seen in books, and recently I have been watching the Tate Walks on Sky Art, and to be able to see these paintings up close and photograph them was special.Every British painter was represented and my favourites were the many pre-raphaelite paintings.I will make every effort to come back here as soon as I can.

10.title: The Crime Museum Uncovered
10.review: For this particular exhibition at the Museum of London it cost 12 per person, and once there we seriously considered demanding our money back.Granted, it was the first day it was open and was thus sure to be busy, but so many people were crammed into it that one could barely move.A friend described it as like waiting in a queue for a theme park ride, and that's exactly how it was, but sadly throughout the entire trip - slow moving and cramped. It was so crowded one couldn't deviate at all! The museum really needs to review the number of people they let in at any one time, as there were far too many.Also, for the amount of money paid, the exhibition was far too small. Yes, there were some interesting artifacts on display, but only two people at a time could look at them, and the exhibition itself was tiny. I think a price of 5 at most would be sufficient. There also needed to be much more literature rather than a simple 'blurb' for each item on display - this is a museum, after all!Lastly, there seemed to be no air conditioning, and with so many people in there it was not a pleasant place to be - by the end we gave up and left without watching the video.There are other parts of the museum that are fascinating, and the staff are friendly, hence two stars rather than one, but I really think that for this particular exhibition, something that could have been a great asset has instead been a major disappointment.Oh, and the automatic taps in the toilets didn't work either!

11.title: Beasts of London a tad underwhelming
11.review: Despite living nearby, this was my first time in the Museum of London. The museum itself was amazing, if only Id left myself more time to explore it in its entirety. The Beasts of London exhibit was a whim decision - it looked really interesting - but I came away a little underwhelmed. I felt there was a heavy emphasis on children with little to entertain and inform any older visitors. It could have benefited from some of the darker stories London has to offer (without any comedic voice acting), such as the case of Jacco Macacco, the London bear baiting craze, and the fate of Chunee the elephant (I assumed the elephant on the poster was an allusion to his story). If its an exhibit primarily for kids, a notice to that effect would have been helpful. Ill definitely be back to explore the museum some more, but a topic like Londons animal history could be a great deal more universally presented.

12.title: Dont waste your money on The Beasts of London
12.review: We were looking forward to seeing The Beasts of London. As a family this cost 30. The trailer on the web looks exciting and immersive. This is definitely not what it is! You walk from room to room with projections of animals on the walls you can hardly see, with a narration which is barely audible as all the sounds are coming through from other rooms. It definitely felt like going back in time cinematically, not in a good way. Totally boring and a waste of money!

13.title: The Beasts of London
13.review: Quite disappointed. Poor animation, not clear sounds, the information is presented in a boring way. For a paid attraction the expectations are higher. We wont be coming back. The rest of museum is fine. Expensive item in the shop.

14.title: Excellent Museum
14.review: Its slightly of the beaten track but easily reachable by tube, and its free. We only had time to do the gallery from the Great fire of London to present day but it was well worth. Some great exhibits and plenty of time required to do it justice, give a donation on your way out.

15.title: A gem of a museum in a city filled with museums!
15.review: I have visited London many times, and have visited all those big, famous museums - the Tate, the V&A, the Natural History Museum, etc etc. For some reason, I hadn't ever made it over to the Museum of London! What an error! It should absolutely be on your list of Must-See museums when you visit! The museum presents a full history of London, from prehistoric times to the present, and is a super interactive, fun place. One of the many highlights includes a small recreation of a Victorian-era street - great photo ops abound! It is also very close to the old London Wall, which is just steps away from the museum (you can see a portion of it from inside the museum too) and also worth a visit. When planning your London itinerary, may I recommend breakfast at the London Wall restaurant, which is just next door to the Museum of London (They serve a full English breakfast!) followed by at least 2 hours at the museum, about 20-30 minutes to explore the London Wall (the actual wall, not the restaurant!) outside, and then maybe pop on over to St. Paul's Cathedral, which is just down the road.

16.title: Beasts of London paid 'Exhibition'
16.review: Incredibly disappointed. Expected an exhibition featuring brewery dray horses, Downing Street cat, cockfight playbills, inspired pottery...  Received tiny areas showing poorly animated, poor quality films which were loud, overpowered each other and on occassion made you feel unwell. Possibly, this exhibition would be more acceptable if it claimed to be directed only at children but lacked sufficient clarity or content to continuously entertain them (certainly not the child visiting at the same time). We left the area after ten minutes.Very few artefacts (told there was 1.5minutes betwween zoned films in which to look at displays).. More would have been achieved if the films were edited into one continuous showing using a room that could accomodate them. However, that would not have repaired the rump of the black horse on The Mall!No explanation of the format was given until the entrance was reached. I would have preferred to pay an entrance fee for the museum than feel misled into paying to see this 'spectacle'. The best thing about it were the foyer ads.Incidentally, lower cafe had a cream tea offer but tea machine broken so sent us to lobby cafe. It had tea but no scones! Explained and suggested that perhaps they could be transferred from downstairs.Didn't happen.I enjoyed the Musuem many years ago when it focussed on the vibrant history of London (not the far Thames Valley). Today even the Great Fire of London model was static/broken?

17.title: Disappointed latest exhibition
17.review: I've always thought the activities thrown by Museum of London were good in the past hence why I did not hesitate to book the Beast of London for a family of 4.However, I was quite disappointed.  Children moved from one 'room' to another to listen to some narration with poor acoustics with some animation.  At one point, it wasn't clear that the giant pigeon was also a 'room' too which I think threw other guests too as by the time I entered the last room, other guests other than those in our group joined us making it even more difficult to engage there.Considering how much we paid, I was expecting a lot more interaction...
